text:
Tompkins Avenue, at the S. W. corner of Chestnut Avenue, showing the Giuseppe Garibaldi House, in which the great Italian patriot lived with his friend Meucci, the candlemaker, from 1851 to 1853. The house was dedicated as a memorial on July 4, 1907 and is now protected by a temple-like structure. A bust of Garibaldi adorns the entrance to the memorial.

About 1900

Photo By Mildenburg
From P. L. Sperr Collection

Tompkins Ave., at the S.W. corner of Chestnut Ave., showing the Garibaldi Memorial. The house in which Giuseppe Garibaldi lived with his friend Meucci from 1851 to 1853 stands inside the memorial. A bust of the great Italian patriot is also shown.

1924.

P. L. Sperr.

A bust of the great Italian patriot is also shown. This is a set of three views taken the same day.

Tompkins Avenue, west side, between Chestnut Avenue and Shaughnessy Lane, showing a new city playground under construction on the W. H. White property. The view is northeastward toward Tompkins Avenue from Shaughnessy Lane and shows the Garibaldi Memorial on the former.

Tompkins Avenue, at the S. W. corner of Chestnut Avenue, showing the Garibaldi Memorial. The dwelling in which Giuseppe Garibaldi, the great Italian liberator, lived with his friend Meucci from 1851 to 1853 stands inside the Memorial.

November 30, 1937

Berenice Abbott
